title: How do cloud-native environments handle updates and patch management?

content:
Cloud-native environments handle updates and patch management through automation, declarative operations, and immutable infrastructure principles. This is crucial as it ensures systems are secure, reliable, and can quickly respond to vulnerabilities or functional requirements, enabling zero-downtime or near-zero-downtime updates in highly dynamic environments to support continuous delivery.

Core mechanisms include: the use of container images (immutable, updates require building new images), declarative deployment tools (such as Kubernetes Deployment, which defines the desired state with controllers executing rolling updates), service meshes (enabling fine-grained traffic control to support canary/blue-green deployments), and CI/CD pipelines (fully automated building, testing, and deployment). The GitOps model ensures version control and automated synchronization of infrastructure as code. This reduces human error, improves environmental consistency, speeds up change implementation, and enhances traceability.

Processing steps typically involve: automated vulnerability scans triggering patch builds; CI pipelines building new container images and pushing them to registries; defining update strategies (rolling update/recreate) through declarative configurations (such as K8s YAML or Helm Charts); deployment controllers coordinating the gradual replacement of Pods; validating fine-grained traffic switching with service meshes or Ingress; and automatic rollback if necessary. Its business value lies in minimizing downtime risks, accelerating security compliance responses, ensuring service availability, and continuously delivering value.
